data.title: On benchmark data set, question-answering system halves error rate
data.description: Improvements come from new transfer learning method, new publicly released data set.

data.title: Web Search and Data Mining conference is “extraordinarily selective”
data.description: Only 15% of submissions to “boutique” conference are accepted; four Amazon papers to be presented.

data.title: Preserving privacy in analyses of textual data
data.description: New "Mad Libs" technique for replacing words in individual sentences is grounded in metric differential privacy.

data.title: How we taught Alexa to correct her own defects
data.description: Self-learning system uses customers’ rephrased requests as implicit error signals.

data.title: The research behind Alexa’s popular whispered speech
data.description: According to listener tests, whispers produced by a new machine learning model sound as natural as vocoded human whispers.

data.title: Why do customers buy seemingly irrelevant products?
data.description: Analysis points to better algorithms for product discovery.

data.title: Multilingual shopping systems
data.description: Training a product discovery system on many languages at once improves performance in all of them.

data.title: Amazon at AEA: The crossroads of economics and AI
data.description: Pat Bajari, VP and chief economist for Amazon's Core AI group, on his team's new research and what it says about economists' role at Amazon.

data.title: Alexa’s ASRU papers concentrate on extracting high-value training data
data.description: Related data selection techniques yield benefits for both speech recognition and natural-language understanding.

data.title: 3 important themes from Amazon's 2019 NeurIPS papers
data.description: Time series forecasting, bandit problems, and optimization are integral to Amazon's efforts to deliver better value for its customers.

data.title: Alexa at five: looking back, looking forward
data.description: Today is the fifth anniversary of the launch of the Amazon Echo, so in a talk I gave yesterday at the Web Summit in Lisbon, I looked at how far Alexa has come and where we’re heading next.

data.title: Improving cross-lingual transfer learning by filtering training data
data.authors: Quynh Ngoc Thi Do, Judith Gaspers
data.description: In the past year, we’ve published several papers demonstrating that a natural-language-understanding model trained in one language, then re-trained in another, can outperform a model trained from scratch in the second language.

data.title: The FEVER data set: What doesn’t kill it will make it stronger
data.description: This year at the Conference on Empirical Methods in Natural-Language Processing (EMNLP), we will cohost the Second Workshop on Fact Extraction and Verification — or FEVER — which will explore techniques for automatically assessing the veracity of factual assertions online.

data.title: Tools for generating synthetic data helped bootstrap Alexa’s new-language releases
data.description: In the past few weeks, Amazon announced versions of Alexa in three new languages: Hindi, U.S. Spanish, and Brazilian Portuguese.

data.title: Amazon Releases New Public Data Set to Help Address “Cocktail Party” Problem
data.description: Amazon today announced the public release of a new data set that will help speech scientists address the difficult problem of separating speech signals in reverberant rooms with multiple speakers.

data.title: How to construct the optimal neural architecture for your machine learning task
data.description: By reframing the problem of function approximation, a new analysis suggests ways to optimize neural architectures.

data.title: Amazon releases data set of annotated conversations to aid development of socialbots
data.description: Today I am happy to announce the public release of the Topical Chat Dataset, a text-based collection of more than 235,000 utterances (over 4,700,000 words) that will help support high-quality, repeatable research in the field of dialogue systems.

data.title: Turning Dialogue Tracking into a Reading Comprehension Problem
data.description: During a conversation between a customer and a dialogue system like Alexa’s, the system must not only understand what the customer is saying currently but also remember the conversation history. Only by combining the history with the current utterance can the system truly understand the customer’s…

data.title: The 16 Alexa-related papers at this year’s Interspeech
data.description: At next week’s Interspeech, the largest conference on the science and technology of spoken-language processing, Alexa researchers have 16 papers, which span the five core areas of Alexa functionality: device activation, or recognizing speech intended for Alexa and other audio events that require…

data.title: Accelerating parallel training of neural nets
data.description: Earlier this year, we reported a speech recognition system trained on a million hours of data, a feat possible through semi-supervised learning, in which training data is annotated by machines rather than by people.

data.title: New Alexa Research on Task-Oriented Dialogue Systems
data.description: Earlier this year, at Amazon’s re:MARS conference, Alexa head scientist Rohit Prasad unveiled Alexa Conversations, a new service that allows Alexa skill developers to more easily integrate conversational elements into their skills.

data.title: How to Make Neural Language Models Practical for Speech Recognition
data.description: An automatic-speech-recognition system — such as Alexa’s — converts speech into text, and one of its key components is its language model. Given a sequence of words, the language model computes the probability that any given word is the next one.

data.title: Neural TTS Makes Speech Synthesizers More Versatile
data.description: A text-to-speech system, which converts written text into synthesized speech, is what allows Alexa to respond verbally to requests or commands. Through a service called Amazon Polly, text-to-speech is also a technology that Amazon Web Services offers to its customers.

data.title: New AI system helps accelerate Alexa skill development
data.description: Embedding entity names from diverse skills in a shared representations space enables system to suggest neglected entity names with 88.5% accuracy.

data.title: More-Efficient Machine Learning Models for On-Device Operation
data.authors: Chieh-Chi Kao, Ming Sun, Bowen Shi
data.description: Neural networks are responsible for most recent advances in artificial intelligence, including many of Alexa’s latest capabilities. But neural networks tend to be large and unwieldy, and in recent years, the Alexa team has been investigating techniques for making them efficient enough to run…

data.title: Representing Data at Three Levels of Generality Improves Multitask Machine Learning
data.description: Alexa currently has more than 90,000 skills, or abilities contributed by third-party developers — the Uber ride-sharing skill, the Jeopardy! trivia game skill, the Starbucks drink-ordering skill, and so on.

data.title: Who’s on First? How Alexa Is Learning to Resolve Referring Terms
data.description: This year, at the Association for Computational Linguistics’ Workshop on Natural-Language Processing for Conversational AI, my colleagues and I won one of two best-paper awards for our work on slot carryover.

data.title: Teaching computers to answer complex questions
data.description: Computerized question-answering systems usually take one of two approaches. Either they do a text search and try to infer the semantic relationships between entities named in the text, or they explore a hand-curated knowledge graph, a data structure that directly encodes relationships among…

data.title: 2019 Amazon Research Awards CFP launch announcement
data.description: This month, Amazon announced the 11 focus areas of the 2019 Amazon Research Awards.

data.title: Bringing the Power of Neural Networks to the Problem of Search
data.description: Using machine learning to train information retrieval models — such as Internet search engines — is difficult because it requires so much manually annotated data. Of course, training most machine learning systems requires manually annotated data, but because information retrieval models must handle…
